benCXsziOWHmUqkzg1bWxg.text: We came following a suggestion of a friend of us. Nice ambient. Really British.Food disappointing: roast monkfish without saltThe butler steak good but nothing special OvervaluedOne visit in your trip to London is more than enough

2X4WLCAaX5oYWswQu6uWnw.text: We were recommended to eat at rules for experience of one of the oldest restaurants in London and traditional food. The decor is great makes you feel like you are transported 100 years ago with all of the traditions of great service. Food gras was delicious, great appetizer. Pies were pretty good though a little salty for my taste. You can hear some great stories if you ask anyone from the staff.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

6h2kxsrQF9utq0vtAKpzPw.text: Our favorite experience at a restaurant abroad - there is nothing like an old school amazing menu, and amazing service. The food is ridiculously good, and the people watching is even better - you could sit next to a duke headed to the newest symphony in town, or tourists from Sydney enjoying their anniversary (actually, exactly who we were sandwiched between).Order... everything. You can't go wrong.

62MebPMlg4i-eSMyu7w8sg.text: Everyone, stop what you are doing and go get a Rules Cocktail. Yes, the cocktail at Rules called The Rules. It rules. The atmosphere was eclectic, old school and very fun. Service was great, food was great, and it served as a perfect place to end our vacation. Skip the wine list and go straight for the cocktails. Well balanced cocktails that don't scream "I have alcohol in me!" and are crafted with care. I started with a green salad. Not sure it was worth the 9 quid but it was REALLY good. For a main course I had the lamb special with mint sauce. Very nice size portion of the lamb, a little fatty though. The mint sauce cut through the fat and lightened it up a big which was nice. The vegetables were cooked to perfection.I finished my meal with the Blood Orange Parfait. Delicious. Blood Orange Sorbet on a crunchy granola crust, very refreshing and unique. The actual blood oranges on the plate had no flavor, however, could have done without.Prices are not for the shallow pocketed. But, you do get a well cooked meal.A knocked off a star because I think the prices were a little too high, though not by much, and our table for two was, quite literally, slanted.

KjzbB8ZJGnei69UjUzNwGw.text: Opening Remarks:-Opened by Thomas Rule in 1787, making it the oldest restaurant in London.-The restaurant owns Lartington Estate in the High Pennies where a lot of hunting goes down, hence the restaurants' emphasis on game birds, roe deer and Belted Galloway beef-In addition to obviously being a restaurant, Rules offers a Cocktail Masterclass for those interested in learning more about classic mixology-On their website, they feature reviews and letters about Rules submitted by famous people including Nigella Lawson circa 1991Ambiance:-Old school doesn't even begin to describe the room there at Rules- the restaurant has been standing since the 1700s and they apparently have not changed a single thing. There are old photos, paintings and busts on the wall of significant British figures, and an abundance of antlers and other hunting gear all around.-The wooden tables are draped in white linens, but in no way will this resemble the high-end dining experience one may be accustomed to. Seriously, the room is more haunted house than Michelin Star.-There are two private dining rooms (which I popped by head into)-The demographic is largely 70+ wealthy folk who are well dressed and definitely not tourists- with my cute summer dress and my camera strapped around my waist, I stood out like a sore thumb.Service:-Service at Rules is professional to say the least- the mature servers wear white collars and black suits and approached the table with a level of sophistication. Despite the high-brow approach, the servers were surprisingly friendly and laid back. -Water glasses were refilled, cutlery replenished as needed, and the meal moved at a very comfortable lunch time pace - in and out in approximately 1 hourDrinks:-A short list of British cocktails like the Black Velvet (Champagne and Guiness-yikes), and the Kate Middleton (Sipsmith, Pinky Vodka, Lillet, Crystallised Violets, and Rose Petals), with London Pride and Draught Guinness on tap. They also serve wine by the glass and bottle.-We had a long day ahead of us so asked for an off-the-menu unsweetened iced tea, which the chef made for us from scratch.Food:-Old school British with a heavily focus on game meats like Guinea Fowl, quail, rabbit, duck, pigeon, roe deer and more-The menu is divided into Oysters, First Courses, Pies, Mains, Veggies, and Puddings and Cheese-Upon our visit it was Grouse season so they had a separate menu for items featuring this game meat (which I had never tasted before!)Pea & Bacon Soup with Crème Fraiche (7.95)Simple but delicious. Very smooth with deliciously salty bits of bacon and just enough luxurious crème fraiche to smooth it out.Dorset Crab on Toast with Heritage Tomatoes & Herb Mayonnaise (15.95)My favourite savoury dish of the meal- the tomatoes were absolutely stunning, and the crab salad was plentiful and not overly dressed with mayo.Grouse Salad with Watercress, Pickled Giroulles, Blackberries and Cobnuts ( 12.50)I definitely liked the flavour of the gamey grouse with the sweet blackberries, but the meat was unpleasantly overcooked and dry.Potatoes Anna (4.50)Simple and comforting, the potatoes were cooked nicely with a good crispy crust and tender interior, but I found them underseasoned.Treacle Sponge Pudding with Custard & Clotted Cream (7.95)Wow. I am so glad I finally got to try treacle because I am officially obsessed. It is a lot like a sticky toffee pudding, but brighter, lighter and sweeter, the pudding had a fabulous citrus flavour to counteract the sweet sticky treacle. Topped off with a generous pour of custard to cut some of that sugar, and I was one happy girl.Closing:-65 including tax and tip ($106 Canadian) - very expensive considering we thought we had eaten relatively light.-While it's certainly not a place I would ever see myself as a regular, I am glad I checked it out for the old school British experience.

xwmu_v8GPYMGYTgZxfOW0g.text: I had a business dinner here several years ago, which involved a foie gras.  Both the foie gras and the dinner companions made me sick immediately and for some time thereafter.  i would recommend staying away from both. In its defense: the place is famous for its age, which may explain the quality of the foie grass.

Qez9a_3-_k8ODgnYFCaIyw.text: Slink upstairs to a red velvet cocktail bar/lounge/drawing room, be theatrically but seriously served expertly mixed drinks by a suited waiter, sit up straight and enjoy the understated elegance of a proper cocktail bar.Current London cocktail prices hover around £8 mark and can be very hit or miss, Rule's menu starts at £14 I believe and every one is a hit.

bFDmEGN2sEgyj4AHEFHqjA.text: First off: if you go make reservations online.  You'll get an email that you might be tempted to ignore, thinking it's just an automatic confirmation... which it is, but it also tells you when you have to leave your table and that you need to reply to confirm your reservation at least 24 hours in advance.In short: the staff isn't worth it.So after a phenomenal experience at Amsterdam's oldest restaurant I decided to check out London's oldest restaurant, too, thinking this would be a nice little tradition wherever I travel.  Wrong.  Live and learn.  The food was good (if overpriced, but I was okay with that), the place was lovely, but the service had a bit to be desired.  It's obvious the restaurant wants to pride itself on being classy, but don't do what it takes to fully get there.  The staff was not friendly or genuinely kind, and a bit standoffish.  After I ordered a main course (that cost 30 pounds) the waiter asked if I wanted a starter.  I said no, but he pointed to some anyway, and told me that the meal took 40 minutes to make.  I told him that was fine and I would drink my wine until then.  Of course, the small meal only took about 15 minutes to arrive and I did not appreciate the obvious up-sell.  It was delicious but small, which again I was okay with, but if I'm paying for an overpriced small meal I expect the staff add to the experience, not detract from it.  Also I noticed that they only had male servers, which didn't sit right with me in this day and age.I would have been happier in a traditional pub with friendly people.  Live and learn.  And only go to De Silveren Spiegel in Amsterdam when I'm in the mood for an upscale yet cozy dining experience with service second to none.

YqOAcbY0uo8_AszQBGVVBA.text: Went here for Easter dinner for a nice beef roast. Very interesting decor...lots to look at. They took us early so that was great because we were starving! We ordered the roast beef for 2 and the portion size was huge! The meal was very nice...except for the slug on the salad..lol..it happens.  They did take off the charge for the wine though so that was very impressive.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Roast rib for 2!

X779LtzoA7W0fgX1CTyWLw.text: Did you, like me, forget to grow up in mid-1800s London? Well then don't fret - just head over to Rules!I was in London on business with a colleague and Rules stood out to us because it is London's oldest restaurant. Like a bunch of self-important Americans, of course we were underdressed, but the staff sat us immediately and were very courteous regardless.They were having a steak special - I forget the exact name - but it was a special type of beef that they only got on occassion. I went for it and was glad I did, it was very delicious.The bottom line is that this place screams old school gentleman's London. Classy staff who are very courteous, excellent wine, and scrumptuous food prepared masterfully. The doorman in the tails was a very nice touch. I hope to visit this place again for a special dinner next time I am in Jolly Ole'.

NEmsFcO29x7dng-Ye3NLyA.text: Dining at Rules feels a bit like being transported back to a bygone era (as in the fantasy rose-tinted version, rather than how things probably really were for most people in the 1800s).It's not hard to imagine having just stepped out of your carriage as the doorman opens the door and sweeps you in from the cold to be cloistered in a velvet covered booth beneath the antlers and copious wall ornaments. The oldest restaurant in London is literally steeped in history and it's all on display. The waiter was happy to discuss and explain the various pictures adorning the walls and encouraged a little tour around on the way to the bathroom to get a good look at everything, which was nice.With so much effort invested in the venue, one might fear the food wouldn't come up to par, but it so did!  For lunch I went for the blade of beef with bone marrow and parsley mash, which was melt in your mouth delicious. And the pies, particularly the steak and kidney pie, were also extremely good, with a thin pastry crust filled with proper meat and accompanied by a rich gravy. Rules is exclusively supplied beef from the Gilmonby herd of pedigree Belted Galloways farmed in the north-east near the Pennines, where they also own Lartington Hall Park estate from which their game is sourced. So that accounts for the quality of the meat.You need to order some sides of vegetables to go with the dishes, and the green beans were cooked perfectly with a bit of crunch still. And everything got washed down with a rather lovely bottle of Saint-Émilion selected from a decently ranging wine list (particularly if you have a preference for French).The choux pastry dessert with creme patissiere, praline & almonds was so light it felt like no effort to eat it all, and it looked exquisite as well. The warm chocolate fondant was also just right, with a hint of mint to take the edge off the richness. It's necessary to book ahead as it was a full lunch service on a Saturday, although there is the option of eating the same menu upstairs in the cocktail bar, which wasn't busy. Throughout the meal the service was attentive without being intrusive but it was a long and relaxed lunch at two and a half hours (although didn't drag - it had just the right balance), so be prepared to take your time, sit back and enjoy it. The cocktail bar looked like the kind of inviting place you could easily lose an entire evening, so certainly something to go back for!

KFeYTjwL0vzgjRD73aW_tw.text: Very mediocre! It is rare that I give so few stars, but this place is awful and highly overrated. The only reason I gave it 2 stars instead of one is because the dessert was actually pretty good (the only plus from the whole night). First they run out of the Kate Middleton cocktail, apparently didn't have one of the ingredients. Then the salad with partridge was bland and not seasoned, just overall underwhelming. The worst was the mains. First the accidentally send our food to the table next to us. They stare at it for about 10 minutes. And then the waiter apologizes and places the food they have been breathing on for a good 10 minutes in front of us. It didn't look touched, but who really knows. It was impossible to get the waiters attention, hence the other couple having to breathe over our food for so long. The waiter highly recommended the hare for main course, said it was his favorite so I thought why not give it a shot. It was inedible!!! Dry, no flavor, just awful. This place does not know a thing about service or good food. And it is definitely a tourist trap that unfortunately my fiancé and I fell into. I work with British ppl and half of them have never even heard of it. And those that have say it's a tourist trap and have never been themselves and never plan on going. Save your time and money and go somewhere else.

KX9RHvJP-YNBRwEog6TckA.text: Rules is quite the place, to say the least!  My friend and I stopped in for lunch on a weekday afternoon while the restaurant was empty, and we had the greatest experience!  We decided on the restaurant after reading about it on the internet and and finding that the restaurant had a great deal of consistently positive reviews.  It is a bit expensive, but London is an expensive city; we decided that this meal was going to be our "splurge."We found classy decor and a relaxing dining environment, with good service to boot (even though we were a tad under-dressed) when we arrived.  We were seated at a table right by the window, which had a good view of both the outside and the other tables inside the restaurant.I ordered the Steak and Kidney Pie, which was absolutely phenomenal!  I had never before tasted anything like it in my life, making it even more exciting.  The flavors all stood out boldly with every bite, and the perfectly-cooked mashed potatoes complemented the dish exquisitely.  My friend ordered the duck, which he thoroughly enjoyed, as well (although I think we both decided that the Steak and Kidney Pie was the best).  For dessert we got the Sticky Toffee Pudding, which was absolutely delicious and left us desperately desiring more.On a side note, this restaurant is really quite formal.  While they don't mind tourists walking in from the street wearing "touristy" clothing, the practice is frowned upon and really downright tacky.  My friend and I felt horribly under-dressed (it's true, we were!), but we were made to feel comfortable.  However, I will certainly dress more nicely if I ever get to go again.Totally recommend this place!  Give it a try!

Ix5ogvneNSaCds4kz-doUw.text: From walking past this place in one December afternoon,  my eye was caught but what looked like a very classic, cosy, almost dickens land of christmas.Rules prides itself on being 'London Oldest Restaurant' and its reputare of previous famous customers. To name a few, Charles Dickens, William Makepeice, and Rules has appeared in several books. I came here for an english tea, and actually really enjoyed my time here. Sure it has its slightly private school nature about it, and you imagine someone shouting ' Jolly Hockey Sticks!' but for me, that all adds to the quintessentially english experience. Nothing to be ridiculed, more like a classic book which is to be savoured over a malt whiskey.

jeL7gjuQrE9apmJ2ms7TrQ.text: This is more a trip to a living museum than a restaurant -it's quit the experience  a must, better value than the "EYE". Think of it this way - you're nobility (elder - Andrew/Harry would never be caught dead here) and along with your courtesan just finished a day of shooting and have come here to dine on the days hunt. Upside you can feel like those tight ass upper crust english blue bloods, act like them, eat like them, be served like them, and spend like then (remember they're stingy when it comes to tipping) for 3 hours. Best way to experience english fare (game) - never had anyone cook it more traditionally or better. Downside you might end up with a permanent pout and nose in the air and become a statistic of the federal bail out plan. Too many tourists and you'll need a set of dentures after trying to tear thru your bird - btw traditional english food is truly more about tradition than taste.

qzXKeJprcMQXe7rgRUUmfA.text: A well respected restaurant. The food is the very best local produce cooked classically but with real flair. The dessert is the real treat, the Raspberry Syllabub is divine. Nice classic decor and a cosy atmosphere but beware it can be noisy and your conversation can be easily overheard. For such a prime location and exceptional food quality I don't find them pricey at all.

4LYH44n-T9PYPH5KhF1DRQ.text: this is a fantastic restaurant, staff brilliant and food excellent. The whole ambience and the interior is just right  but I felt a little crammed in as it was very busy on the night I went. Down-side is that it is very expensive  but you do get what you pay for so I would recommend it to all as a treat.

I_6bWXaqM5Ljny6CSxVycw.text: I had an amazing dinner there when I visited friends in London. Mr. Uncle Peter treated us and we splurged on the finest game meal - fresh from the fields, fine white, excellent dessert. It was a wonderful experience sitting in an establishment that has been around for centuries, it was an honor and I look forward to going there again on my next trip to London. Rules rule!

O9XoNAph3L8vBvBJ_YszEg.text: It's in Covent Garden since 1798. A true english jewel. When you enter you feel like in an english palace, with a lot of history and tradition. The food is really delicious. One of the best plates is the chopsticks. Excellent steaks. The lemon pie was incredible. Cozy, good service. One of the oldest restaurants in London.

S0w0YCXtndjUInz3LvxGUQ.text: Best meal I've ever had!  The rib roast was so good I couldn't stop eating it. It was the best meat I've ever had in my life.  We all actually fought for the green beans and the Yorkshire pudding was perfect. Not just an amazing location with great history but the best meal of my life!  If you don't like waiting go during an off time. We went at 3:30 and it was great!  Every trip to London will include Rules from now on!  It's that good!

2CwaHOjyWMUIj4tuBPdOTg.text: Came here with my parents during my study abroad in college.  A really cool traditional English restaurant, as if you were dining after your game hunts.  Many dishes are from their country-side game reserve, and the menu warns you may find some shot fragments in your dish.  My mother had roast quail and she did find some pieces of shot, kind of weird but gave it an authentic feel!  Would come back here again next time I'm in town, but its a dressy and relatively expensive place, FYI.

l7NuBC4KDFGtkjGTsPdfjA.text: Oldest restaurant in London, amazing traditional British food and beer served in goblets gives it a special touch. Decor of the restaurant is 1700's esque (because it was founded in 1798). The meat is very fresh here and the service is top quality. Rules is a must when in London.

hGN6Z5ySF3K4FrsbwCKMoQ.text: "This is perfect," said my friend as he studied the menu - and he was right. Anyone with a taste for game or traditional English food of exquisite quality will be in their element !!

yHKEsizg8Kh43vcFgveoRA.text: I've eaten at Rules everytime I've visited London. I love the Old English ambiance and that they make no apologizes for their highly carnivorous atmosphere, it's meat for starters, meat for entree and if you please ~ meat for dessert! Vegetarian's need not apply. I love the rib of beef on the bone, lamb chops and rack of lamb. The meat comes from their own farm! They have wonderfully traditional accompaniments such as cream spinach, au gratin potato's sauteed green beans, bake potatos and Yorkshire pudding which I adore! The first time my husband and I went to Rule's, we were with another couple so we shared sticky toffee dessert that was amazing! Now I order my own and if for some crazy reason can't finish it, I bring it back to the hotel for a snack! I also love that its in walking distance to the West End, we love going to the theater in London and this has become a wonderful tradition, Seeing a marvelous play or musical and dinner at Rules Restaurant!

d7fv3OoJ0i-LK_40m5OC-A.text: Caveat: We went here several years ago.As a "landmark" I was a bit apprehensive, however, that concern was quickly removed.  The service was amazing.  If you have a preconceived notion of English food, toss it out the window.  Rules makes great use of wild game and even has a disclaimer on its menu regarding "buckshot" in the food.  I cannot say I had any issues with buckshot, however the food was incredible.  Cooked to perfection.  The desserts were awesome.  Even the other restaurant goers around us were incredibly friendly to a couple of Americans.  We have this at the top of our list the next time we're in London.

mYO2dKN_PL7MHEy-66rLig.text: I wandered in here one night on my own when travelling with work. The staff were charming & the food of excellent quality. I do think that it is slightly over-priced at over £60 for 2 courses, a glass of wine and a G&T, but cannot fault the food or service. The interior is stunning and the traditional menu well-executed. Overall it's a lovely restaurant & would be a great choice for a special meal.

bzMZe8fWUXbqrHuwf3z2LA.text: We were in London and a cab driver told us about Rules.  We came and had a late lunch on a Saturday afternoon.  It was lovely.  We started off with a couple of cocktails then dove into an appetizer of Foie Gras, which was heavenly.  We decided on the roast beef with yorkshire pudding for two as a main course.  London is a hard place to get good food and everything was excellent.  The service was formal, yet friendly and solicitous.  The atmosphere was old world stuffy england yet the people were not.  A wonderful afternoon.

bKwY3FfKk5GTlgr9cWhmjg.text: A fine solid dining experience. Epitome of English stuffyness- without the stuffyness (Did I spell that right - god knows) . Great for dining with parents or future inlaws- they are always impressed.

ylvIL2diktclu1gWKkB67g.text: A fabulous, cozy restaurant in London - my favorite city! My boyfriend and I ended up here rather randomly while on our trip to London. We were staying nearby at the Waldorf Hilton and the concierge mentioned Rules as a nice restaurant for dinner. We did not have reservations on a Sunday night, but we decided we could always just have a few cocktails and relax while we waited for our table. When we arrived we were escorted upstairs to a cozy little corner table. We had great drinks (including 1 very strong cocktail with Absinthe in it) and then headed back downstairs for dinner about 40 minutes later. I ordered a fish entree that was delicious and my boyfriend had the most delicious lamb chops! (and I normally do not like any lamb) The dish was accompanied by a delightful fresh mint sauce! Nothing like the fake mint jelly/sauces you sometimes see. This is a elegant but comfortable and cozy restaurant with great service and great food! I would elaborate more on the food, but I was quite tipsy after that absinthe cocktail and the details of dinner are a bit blurred in my memory. I do know that I will return to this restaurant next time I am in London and would highly recommend it. Also - it is the oldest restaurant in London, which added a fun, historical element to the experience.

b2sQT0cGhJmJY8qNaV5EJg.text: Had dinner for five at Rules on Friday 3rd Sep. Generally a good experience but was let down by the woman at the front of the restaurant who handled reservations, who needs some more training on how to talk to customers.After arriving for a 7:30 reservation I was told (after a lot of panicked flapping around with the reservation list) that the reservation was at 8pm. I explained that the reservation was for 7:30 and offered to show her the Opentable confirmation (I had reconfirmed earlier in the day over the phone to make absolutely sure), but she declined and repeated "The reservation is at 8:00". Not "sorry, we have the reservation down for 8pm. We must have made a mistake; why don't you have a free drink in the bar?", which would be standard procedure in any nice-ish restaurant worth its salt. No attempt at contrition or apology- she seemed to go out of her way to avoid apologizing at all costs.Couldn't really complain so early in the night, and the rest of the meal was good enough to forget about that encounter. However that's the memory of the night that stuck, and given the choices in London these days I don't see any of us returning.

ocHow76Gl3LhyEVL77iKKA.text: Widely regarded as London's oldest restaurant, Rules still thrives in the heart of Covent Garden, thankfully not succumbing to the tourist trap. The dining room is dark and cosy, with a gentlemen's club feel to it, but the food is the real attraction, with its focus on seasonal ingredients, with game being a notable highlight.

cZoNbn88afRmmHZ6A0VQIQ.text: I took my parents here about a year ago while they were visiting me from the States.  In terms of the level of sophisticated traditional English atmosphere this place offers, I don't you could ask for much more.  The décor was properly classic -  a colour scheme of deep wine and gold, and the walls are decked out in beautiful and ornate gilded frames containing images of historical figures who have dined at Rules throughout the centuries, as well as striking pictures of birds, plants and game - it all sets the tone for the meal and gives you the sense that this is going to be a deluxe experience.The service was *amazing* - to a level that I've never even had at the likes of Nobu.  The decorum and politeness with which the staff served was of the caliber you imagine it would have been here a hundred years ago; every detail was considered and attended to with flourish; they pulled out our chairs, wheeled our entrees to us on little carts; presented each person with their course and asked if it met their approval before setting it before them - it felt like the service from another century, when there was a correctness and expected etiquette for everything... it was wonderful to experience service that was so attentive and felt so traditional.  My mom had fish and chips - and the way her chips came so artistically arranged in a sheet of newspaper, was a microcosmic reflection of what seems to be the ethos of this place, especially when it comes to their cuisine - they stick to the old English traditions, but their execution is extremely distinguished. My dad had the fish of the day and my sister ordered a roasted pork dish.  I'm more difficult to please in such places since I'm a vegetarian, but I managed with a nice salad and a side of roasted root vegetables.  For traditional English fare, everyone was pretty satisfied with what they ordered.  But far and away the best gastronomic part of the meal was the pudding.  We ordered the chocolate souffle and the sticky toffee pudding... the soufflé was fine, but the sticky toffee pudding was a mass of melting golden caramel divinity - definitely came very close to some of the best sticky toffee pudding I've ever had.Maybe this is all a little over-the-top for native Brits, but we really enjoyed it - and there were enough businessmen in the place that also seemed to be appreciating the attentive service and traditional fare.  There's something very celebratory about the atmosphere here... it's certainly not the type of place you would take a date, but would be an excellent choice if you were toasting a graduation with your parents or wanted to mark some other similar monumental event.  After all, I believe the polished and traditional experience that Rules delivers may very well be the reason it became an institution for so many notable people over so many generations.

RhDaogtKTrlRrFSnCVouVA.text: I agree with all of the positive things said about Rules. I chose this restaurant because I heard it was baby-friendly, something that is few and far between at white tablecloth restaurants in London! We ate here while on vacation with our five month old (at the earliest dinner seating) and the food and service were top notch! The decor was entertaining/stimulating for our baby, and the Yorkshire Pudding and Spotted Dick met our expectations for old-fashioned authentic British fare. Would go back again!

bskmLB52BtLjF65Xs6A81A.text: We decided to go to this restaurant since it toted being the oldest restaurant in London. It was a beautiful place with nice staff. I got the Stroganoff and my friend got the steak. Both dishes were good but they were not amazing. It was a good experience to eat there however they are a little pricey. If you are looking for absolutely delicious food then I recommend you look elsewhere. If you are looking for historical value then this is the place for you.

nw6M1RSc7nXdjsJS87C5WQ.text: Excellent! I loved it since coming in, beautifully decorated from history. We arrived before our reservation and they took us in early. The food was amazing, it's raised on their own estate. I had the shoulder and filet of hare, it was perfectly done! The dessert was one of the best I've ever had. Definitely coming back!

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Spiced sponge with port ice cream- life changing and one of the best desserts I've ever had. The ice cream was the best ever!
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Filet and shoulder of hair, braised pheasant. Both great!

fMLytWM4Drtqtrqd1NIKNg.text: We were extremely disappointed with our short stay at the Rules restaurant. Decor looks very nice and authentic, but the service was terrible and anti-business!!! We are 2 people and in the middle of the afternoon just wanted to chillax with a bottle of wine and some cheese and gravlax. We ordered 2 starters and 2 cheese plates and a bottle of Pinot blanc that would have costed us over 150£ each! After ordering and waiting 15 mins to get our food, the manager comes to us and says that we have obligatory to get a main course each! It would even have been less costly to do so, but we wanted cheese and gravlax and we not interested in a main course at 3pm since we just had lunch before!!! We had to leave the restaurant because they would not serve us what we wanted to eat! Seems like there's way too many "Rules" in that restaurant. That's a terrible business!

a6SJFpHxmIDqmv5zUamz0A.text: Oh Rules. I grew up hearing about this place. My parents are anglophiles, and ate here on one fabled trip to England during the 1970s. When I came to London for my junior (third) year abroad during my BA, my dad constantly pestered me to visit Rules. I did not. Then I came back five years later to study my MA in London. My dad constantly pestered me to visit Rules. I did. When my mom came to visit me here. And picked up the check.And I'm glad we went.I felt similarly to Michael D. - Rules is not my typical kind of place, but it was much enjoyed. It is a delightful mix of upscale stuffy and quirky English with a great interior. English through and through, oh yes. And definitely delicious, not in spite of its Englishness, but because of it! Mom had the Caesar salad to start, a glass of white, and the fish pie. Smelled so smokey and delicious I wished I had ordered it. I enjoyed roasted pheasant and a glass of red. It was all marvelous and we didn't even have room for dessert!

uoocEbZkc8Iq_BE0-roPxw.text: For my last dinner in London I went to Rules on a recommendation.  This ended up being a very good choice.  I understand why it's the oldest restaurant in London and has stuck around all this time.So I get there and the first thing I notice is the décor.  It's older, bunt done very beautifully, a bit of a mash of painting and game.I started off with the Jerusalem Artichoke Soup, this was excellent and really set the stage for the main course!  The Spiced Leg of Lake District Lamb was my choice, and the lamb was cooked perfectly.  While I can't remember the name of the wine, I know it was wonderful and I believe a Bordeaux.Dessert was inspired, Golden Syrup Sponge Pudding.  This was so good I nearly ordered two of them, but that would have just been too much.  Everything tasted excellent.  Finally I had a pot of the Earl Grey tea, served as loose tea with all that comes with.I would absolutely consider returning here on my next visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Jerusalem Artichoke Soup.
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Spiced Leg of Lake District Lamb.
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Golden Syrup a Sponge Pudding.

aQC83Dr7yPkIS31zDHzoZw.text: 100th review of London's oldest restaurant.----------------------------------I had never been to Rules in all the time that I lived in London in the 1990s. I had never even heard of it. I suppose I was young and didn't go to places like this in my 20s. Probably I would not have even had a place like this on my radar.For our 5th wedding anniversary I took my wife to London and chose Rules for the anniversary dinner. The world always puts British food as a butt of a joke. They mark it as bland and overcooked, but the truth is that when done well, though simple, can stand on its own against any cuisine. Rules is the best example of this.We walked over from our hotel that sat below Trafalgar Square, though Covent Garden and on to Maiden Lane where Rules is located. Rules is not your typical restaurant. It cannot be put into a box as one thing. It is both formal and casual-quirky and traditional. It is all that is British through and through.I brought my own bottle of wine, which they do not like and charge a £25 corkage fee for, but I had chosen the wine five years earlier for this specific night and was not going to deviate from my plan. They have a great wine list, and I probably would have done better, as far as pairing, if I had used their sommelier.I started dinner with the Foie Gras Terrine with apricot & toast and Ting had a half dozen Duchy of Cornwall Rock Oysters. The Foie Gras was rich and buttery, like silk if it could melt. The oysters tasted of the dark, cold, salty sea and could not have been fresher.My main course was Scallops with Braised Pork Cheeks, carrot & ginger, and hers the Fillet of Sea Bass with white beans, summer vegetables & a light basil broth. Both were magnificent. My scallops were sweet and tender and the cheek separated at the touch of the fork. The bass was flavorful and perfectly cooked. The vegetables and broth that accompanied it were subtle and delicious.We both have a sweet tooth and I love English desserts. We shared two-the Sticky Toffee Pudding with caramelised walnuts and the Apple & Blackberry Crumble with custard. Both were exactly as they should be-toothsome and traditional.By far the best part of the evening was sitting across from my beautiful wife of five years and telling her that they were the best of my life._____

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Sticky toffee pudding
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Fillet of Sea Bass.
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Scallops with Braised Pork Cheeks.

gmDEsKl-mRYieFdjMukGBw.text: Just like no visit to Paris is complete without a visit to an old-school bistro, no visit to London is complete without a stop at Rules.  London's oldest restaurant for some proper British fare.For my first trip to London, I wanted to experience authentic, traditional British food and Rules was the perfect restaurant for my first taste.   Rules is filled with history - from the red velvet drapes to all of the oil paintings of aristocrats lining the walls, eating at Rules feels like you've just stepped into a posh hunting lodge (however, it can fill a bit stuffy).  Expect formal and brisk service which can be a little stodgy at times, but it was an experience nonetheless.  You definitely have to get the Kate Middleton cocktail.  I had a very refreshing watercress soup and three different varieties of oysters which all tasted fresh and of the ocean.  I was a little disappointed with the cheese selection.  Since it was served last, was hoping it would have come with a sweet accompaniment like honey or nuts instead of onion jam.

6iUr7P4BWckdPHmxUAmCag.text: If you want to impress, this is the place.  The history,  the decor, the food and the service - everything is exceptional.  I've been here twice during one trip and it did not disappoint.  It has lasted a long time (oldest restaurant in London) and the reason why is because it's great! Rules get's my patented Four Thumbs Up!

ivueZ0YHRswj_6miKeQyFA.text: Food is mediocre and the service is not good at all. I understand this is the oldest restaurant in London, but I was underwhelmed. I was really hoping this would be good since I live in the US. This meal has messed up my night. I paid $62 US dollars for this....sigh....

ah_LouIcJNwHTOwb26tWCA.text: This place was definitely something to behold.  If Rules is to be called a "tourist trap", I'm thankful that it's a tourist trap done right (Not actually sure I'd classify it that way, to be honest!)Apparently, as this is London's oldest restaurant, there was a lot done to preserve its original integrity. Founded in 1798, the decor, the ambiance is so -different- from anything I've ever been to.I'm a bit of a dreamer, and I found myself wondering what it was like, when it opened. Pale women, curly hair framing their face, in their fashionable empire gowns, comfortable, laughing. And their partners, men with short hair, sideburns, carrying their hats as they led their ladies in. It's a thing of wonder to feel the ghosts of generations pass through you when you enter a restaurant - not literal ghosts, of course, but just - hearing the laughter and the warmth that once was. It's not hard to imagine - the floor, the ceiling (oh, the ceiling!) can be stared at for hours. Compared to the feeling you get by being here, the food is nearly inconsequential - but it is solid, good British food. I would've really liked for their to have been a cod option with the fish and chips, but the haddock was still quite nice. This place is only slightly pricey, but not pricey compared to the ambiance and the joy of having eaten here. I've definitely paid more for a burger in the USA. Going to Rules should be a rule! (I almost went with 'Rules RULES!' but that just seemed silly, ha!)

2BEOAxtc7MG6vMQRh_AoVg.text: The rib of beef for two and the sides was delicious and enough for two. Traditional British food. Awesome environment.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

JCRoJnDNMQGReuvFfDRXDA.text: Rules has a claim that it's the oldest restaurant in London, its other claim is that is can do 'English cuisine' very well... Well, it has every right to both claims. We couldn't get a seat until 9pm on Saturday but still worth the late dinning. Service was very good, and cheerful (our waitress was), décor comfortable and fun (even the Thatcher paintings). The menu really did have wide range to choose from, and what we had ordered was cooked to perfection and tasted delicious. This is a 'must do' restaurant, you will not be disappointed.

B3zTxphuG57Bm2QHi1WMDA.text: We came here just for the sticky toffee pudding (which was sublime), but enjoyed the rest of the meal just as much.I had the filet, and while it wasn't the best I've ever had, it was enjoyable, juicy, and flavorful. The salad was fresh and made with quality ingredients.A cozy place, decorated like the living room of a fine manor staffed by people with  a similar disposition. Definitely not the most relaxed place in the world. It was quiet and a tad stuffy, but we never felt uncomfortable. The waiter and maitre d' were both gracious and attentive.

wOhPWSMiQo9VMNx9qwV_KQ.text: Charming and elegant, I highly recommend Rules Restaurant.  I visited recently for dinner with a few friends and we all thoroughly enjoyed our evening.  The decor is a major part of the experience and was beautiful; think Downton Abbey with some bonus antlers on plaques.  The food was very good and reflected a clear respect for the classics.  We sampled a few of their heirloom beef specials, the foie gras terrine with blood orange coulis, venison carpaccio, the roasted beef rib and yorkshire pudding for two, the chocolate fondant, and the rhubarb crumble.

qFW8hsI1jPD9Anv7BbfnOg.text: Awesome birthday dinner!The rib roast was very good - made even better by the horseradishThe game soup was a wonderful surpriseThe Mac and cheese was so yummiest that I could have made a meal out of itDon't miss the sticky toffee pudding for desert Allow yourself some time to appreciate the great service and food

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Yorkshire pudding and rib roast

Gn2Hef2H35NOVWP-O1Omjg.text: Items experienced:Whole Wheat Bread with ButterCured Duck Breast with Endive, Candied Nuts, Stilton DressingChicken, Bacon, Tarragon PieDouble Cooked ChipsAmericanoSticky Toffee Pudding with Caramelized WalnutsGolden Syrup Sponge Pudding with CustardProudly presenting itself as London's Oldest Restaurant I generally knew that venerable Rules Restaurant on Maiden Lane was unlikely to wow after lunch at The Fat Duck but with modest expectations of British classics served in a storied environment I booked a table for one at 7:00pm, several hundred World Cup revelers crowding the streets and unfortunately rendering me nearly ten minutes late.  Officially listed as a historic building and serving patrons since 1798 in grand confines heavy with wood and ornamentation it was by a rather stiff maitre d' that I was greeted on entry and with my tardiness duly noted I offered my apologies, his mood somewhat softening as he showed me the way to a spacious two-top with a wide view of the room.  Obviously a space frequented by tourists but seated with natives both left and right it was after a short wait that my server arrived and with menus for food and wine offered I declined the later and briefly perused the specials, none particularly enthralling and thus leaving me to the things I'd targeted before walking through the doors.  Bustling and busy with service not particularly as refined as the tuxedos would indicate it was again after some delay that my first plate arrived and requesting some bread to accompany the salad my starter would prove pleasant, the funky stilton and tender duck finding their foil in crisp greens and sugared nuts.  With the kitchen apparently finding its footing after my first course as four tables received food in a near-simultaneous fashion it was in another duo that I indulged for my main course and although the soufflé-style chips proved a touch less crisp than I'd have preferred the golden pie was delicious - a tall and proud pastry teaming with tender chicken, smoky pork, and earthy aromatics.  At this point impressed enough by food to say I'd made a suitable choice it was to desserts that I turned and with an Americano requested in accompaniment the two classics I'd sought on several prior menus soon arrived - the sticky toffee pudding a toothache inducing classic but nowhere near as rousing as the subtle vanilla sponge, a sort of booze-less baba ready to soak up every drop of warm custard served at its side.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. ...and a lil more custard for ya.
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Golden Syrup Sponge Pudding with Custard
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

0798Us9C0Aw0OCuf9lUFJQ.text: I try to dine at Rule's whenever I am in London.  I have sent friends here, celebrated special occasions, and have always had a very fine, simple dinner done perfectly and as perfectly served as prepared.  One one occasion I e-mailed Rule's to order champagne for Canadian friends who were visiting, and it went through without a hitch.  Another time they gave me a menu to take home to an old lady in Seattle who used to dine at Rule's just after the war.Make reservations long in advance, but enjoy the wonderful traditional cooking; the venison is recommended enthusiastically.

KHGoA38WNLkBoiROytytdw.text: We weren't too hungry, so went straight for the mains. We shared an aged rib of beef with some good old fashioned Yorkshire pudding and potato. The meat was cooked wonderfully, it had the perfect smoky and crispy texture on the outside, very moist and tender from the inside and really well seasoned. Deseret of rum Baba was also a winner, the aroma of the rum was defined. It had the perfect balance of bitter sweetness and I especially enjoyed the black cardamom, which it really lifted up the warmth spice element on the plate without being too dominating, it was indeed a very fine winter pudding.

pOspPllqYvU1wZQEvFmrqw.text: I'm so disappointed- the recipes are not the same. We wanted to share Rules with our grandchildren but it has become an ordinary tourist trap. The food was ok not special - minimal flavor and no attention to the special touches that made Rules unique.  My Fish soup lacked pizazz could have come from a can,the Dover Sole was bland with a munierre sauce that tasted like melted butter.  But how dare they change the Sticky Toffee Pudding!  From an outstanding dessert individually made swimming in butterscotch sauce and Creme Anglais to an ordinary date sheet cake with a drizzle of sauce and a spoonful of sour cream. How sad. I always looked forward to coming on every trip to London but I will not ever be back there again.

1EioNJTX-ljFi_F_zGaRWg.text: In defense of Rules....Rules, like St. Paul's is eternal.  With its odd traditional and wonderful offerings It stands the tests of times; the Blitz, politicians, the sexual revolution and the frequent tourists in from the provinces for a "night at the Theatre".I find great comfort in dining here.  It is consistently fine.  The service is superb. Like Rules, our family's London roots go back to the early 1800's.  For generations Rules has fed our family through lunches and late nights.  I will never forget the maitre di greeting my mother by name after a 20+ year absence in the late-70's and gently joking that is was a bit early in the evening to be seeing her.I call "foul" on those declaring this old friend a tourist trap.  Perhaps that sort of comment speaks more to the yelper's not possessing the appropriate demeanor to pass as a Londoner.

L3oe3VX3PS_upxZjkPks3A.text: I think their food are from 1798 as well...Veal: well.. You have to taste with your eyes first.. It looks like 7£ food, and taste like 10£. But cost 30£Oyster: it's just ok, but too expensive. The yearprobably is the only thing left here.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. oyster.. Overpriced
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. veal.. Overcooked

XkJlGrFw7q9OSsJuEIfkrg.text: Excellent food, the service is mediocre. Our experience was really just ok. For having the history and popularity we expected much friendlier staff. The first person we encountered at check in began to argue with me about the two reservations I made and not listening to what I was saying and trying to explain. They have limited tables for large groups so call to reserve a table for 6 and don't make separate reservations. Even though they say they cancel them, I not having seen this on their website, was able to confirm both over the phone as they require it 24 hours in advance. After diffusing this man's anger he was able to accommodate us at two tables next to one another which is what I was trying to explain I wanted and what I was told to do when I confirmed our reservation. If it hadn't been my husband's desire to dine here for his birthday we would have left given the circumstances. Wow ere there on March 9th.

EH1fC46PJdBqbhwW7eC8jg.text: The food was very good I have to say, but a little too pretentious for me and I would not return based on the atmosphere and experience. They food was expensive as well for the amount served like we ordered the rump roast and they only served 3 measly thin slices of beef with overabundance of Yorkshire pudding. I ordered the pheasant and it was perfectly done and rich. My other friend ordered the pig cheeks and they were very tender and well done, too. I did enjoy the sticky toffee pudding for dessert.

8hgE1BQFVVc2X8XvpaZgPQ.text: I don't think it gets more classically British than Rules. It's like you stepped into the 1800's and everyone just finished a hunt and was looking for a nice warm meal and a stiff drink.  The best food to order is obviously the game and a bottle of red wine, can't go wrong with that.  I had venison, it was cooked perfectly.  The staff is pretty formal, a little uptight if anything, but with the reputation of this establishment, I suppose they have a right too.

K4YB7uEKfhJaNwjR0Q_ugQ.text: Classic English cuisine in a classy setting in London. I went here on the recommendation of a British friend and wasn't disappointed. Atmosphere was classy and mildly "stuffy" but in a good/traditional way. I didn't feel out of place in my business casual attire (no suit/tie retired), but I wouldn't come in with anything less.We had a couple glasses of wine each, and traditional English game-focused dishes. Topped it off with some custard desserts that didn't disappoint. Definitely consider making a reservation as it was pretty crowded when we were there (Sunday night, November).

gT1wv7jr2ttPrJXCfyKJEg.text: I liked the restaurant but the flavoring was a little bland for me.  I think the restaurant must very British. They offered lamb and some kind of bird but went for the Shepard's pie or something similar. Atmosphere is a must try.

8sys_oxtHqVvr_mLuC6W4g.text: Rules is a fabulous restaurant.  The meat and game were delicious.  The boar pie was fabulous.  The Stilton cheese dessert was the perfect ending to an outstanding meal.

hk36rGmgaCkuEB2ZA0gaSw.text: This was an over rated over priced restaurant. The service was brusque and clearly the staff were more impressed with the reputation of the restaurant rather than impressing the current clientele. I chose the venison and if I got 100 grams it was a lot ...and that cost £35. I've eaten at Michelin star restaurants..this one certainly wasn't. Will never go back.

pqAMI57n5I1sCXnGRPoM0g.text: I was afraid it was surviving on its name of being the oldest restaurant in London but I now know there's a good reason it has been around so long. The service was professional and pleasant. I was afraid at first that it seemed a bit too cold but the waitstaff warmed up and got friendlier in response to us so I decided they let the guests set the pace. The food was delicious and the atmosphere was warm and charming. I couldn't decide between the venison and the duck so we ordered both and shared and I found both to be very tasty. Game can be tricky but it was cooked perfectly. As far as price, I did not consider it overly expensive but I live in Manhattan so everything is relative. I would gladly return.

Qk8vMvW3f1LOXqiLLEod0g.text: Upon recommendation from friends, my daughter and I made a lunch reservation.  We ordered a "ladies'" lunch of two starters and a cocktail each.  The snooty waiter informs us they cannot serve alcohol unless an entree is ordered and off he goes to check with the maitre d'.  They both return to the table and so we say nix the drinks, we'll just have the food.  Now, the "rule" changes and we must order an entree with or without alcohol, even if we split it.  I asked why the "rule" is not posted on the menu or anywhere else, and they have no answer for this.  We don't take to ordering more food than we want, so we leave.  The restaurant was practically empty.

HJVnVMleJV5A_4GTnv44MA.text: Classical English food in a rather ornate setting, Rules has been around for decades. It's a great place for a celebration and the restaurant looks brilliant. However I think it relies more on it's reputation now than the food itself. We had starters which were excellent, game terrine, potted shrimp and a game broth. They were all well prepared and delivered by an immaculately attired waiter. The main course however, could have been better, The roast beef, their special was a little too well done, and the amount that you receive is a little lacking, especially when compared to the vegetables provided. The Yorkshire pudding was overdone as well. The horseradish was delivered in a huge spoonful for my plate though, slightly overdoing it as I didn't even eat half.The lamb was similarly received but the partridge was loved by the recipient. No room left for dessert however so we skipped it and went upstairs to look at the bar, one of the oldest around and very ornate. Not needing another drink, we headed for the entrance, picked up our jackets, were bid goodbye by the doorman and headed off into the evening.

9e2UBe-cC9363ZdF7NEtGA.text: So the oldest restaurant in London unfortunately held too high of expectations for me.  I made a reservation for lunch for my family.  The day of the meal, I received an email saying that there was no formal dress code, but men could not wear shorts.  My brother left to go back to the hotel, got stuck in London traffic, and decided not to come.  For an American, it's hard to understand this no shorts rule, so I was a bit miffed at the whole experience alreKiady.  I tried to cancel and the manager said he would have to charge me for cancelling the reservation.  I could understand for a Friday or Saturday night, but a Tuesday lunch cancellation fee?  At 1:45PM?  Not exactly high season.  The atmosphere is as stuffy as you would expect.  Crowded quarters, and lots of game related decor.Service was nice.  My water glass never was empty for too long.Food was mediocre.  I was told by my London friend to order the specials, so I had the beef tongue.  It was okay, but the 7GBP beef tongue I had at John's Salt Beef in Fitzrovia was way better.We also tried the rabbit.  Standard.Kidney and steak pudding was super disappointing.  Granted, I have never been a fan of kidneys, but the steak was just bland and slightly overcooked.  The pudding covering was soggy and flavorless, just an ugly piece of food as well.Not really sure how this place has survived, but I suppose it's just traditional London.

FMZW7tO7NVBZ4YCrKGi41g.text: I had no idea what I was in for when I showed up. This place is so old school fancy! Next time I would dress nicer but we still had a wonderful time. The ambiance and history alone make this place a great dinner choice. I had the duck which I give an A+ and my boyfriend had the scallops which were tasty but I'd recommend ordering a meat dish if you are on the hungry side. The scallops run small.

L1xBKVpwD7_yikMZAXTaTg.text: Devastating. I used to frequent Rules as a child and always recommended my friends abroad to dine here for a truly magical British experience. Pies overflowing the with gravy, everything is bountifuland steaming hot with hushed tones and austere dining with wonderful wait staff. It's been 4 yrs since I have been here and I repent. I repent for sending anyone to this horrific place. The food was disgusting. The steak and kidney pie is better bought at Waitrose and heated in the oven. The kidneys were grey bullets, the gravy non existent and the greens were sautéed in garlic !! Has this chef been to a canteen in England ?? The pigeon was good but it sat on a bed of ... Watercress with Parma ham with mustard blobs and balsamic reduced liquid ??? Again, has this chef even visited an English kitchen ?? Or is this 2005??? And the cherry on top was the server. God knows it's not his fault. He has been trained by some orangutan of a manager.The gratuity was included in the bill which, I questioned and his delightful answer, in his foreign accent was "in London, you see always". As someone who grew up in London England, this was absolute rot and obscene!! How rude !!! How dare he say this to a paying customer especially when the receipt says specifically that it is not compulsory and can be removed at request. I was devastated. My childhood treat has been ruined on this terrible night. I will tell all my foreign friends visiting what a tourist trap this has become. The portraits on the walls were all weeping for the good old days, ashamed of what this has become. It was recovered however when i went to St John's in Smithfields and had a delicious dessert straight after. Their bill certainly did NOT have the gratuity on it and it was wonderful as always.

CIgDUbNBmKV5hkSI9HtR5Q.text: Ok food, abhorrent staff.  I have been here a few times and even recommended it to my friends in the past.  Never again and I will be telling others of my experience. Came with reservations at 8:30PM on a Thursday for dinner.  Group of 3 adults and one 2 year old toddler. As soon as we entered, staff in front asked to check our coats, but looked at us condescendingly since we asked if we could leave our stroller up front as well. They said they had no place to put it. Ok... so we asked if we could take it in.  They said no, leave it up front. We ordered 4 main courses between the 3 of us.  We didn't have lunch and wanted to try a few items.  Waitress said rudely "That's four entrees for three people?"  Yes, I could add that up too. Took a while to get our food.  My nephew (the 2-year old) got off the booth twice to come over to me and ask if he could walk around. Waitress admonished him both times for getting out of the booth.  When the meal finally came, he fell asleep and didn't wake up until we got in the taxi.  Wait staff never came to check on us even though it took 45 minutes to get our food and our drinks were empty. No, the restaurant was not full.  Staff kept looking at us with a sour expression whenever we were able to flag them down. When we were leaving, table next to us noticed my nephew and said how well behaved he was.  I told them about our experience and they empathized by saying the staff could "Sod off."Restaurant should indicate that families with children are not welcome. If that was the case, we wouldn't have bothered to come and it would have saved them the effort of giving us the dirty looks.

gFMuTdnM6saSfNoeEdtaTg.text: Got a 8:30pm reservation for 1 on Sunday night. That's a bit later than I'm used to but boy am I glad I got it and kept the reservation! So so: fish soup. Good and Interesting: beer in a silver mug. I had Guiness and it stayed cold to the last drop!All the desserts looked great...I had the dark chocolate...it was moist and the bottom was crunchy (maybe toffee?)Great: I tried 2 of all three oysters. Except for the size, I couldnt tell the difference in taste asnthey were all so fresh!My main was rabbit. I got to say it was the best rabbit I've  had....juicy, not gamey at all and the roasted/baked peppers and potatoes complemented the duck very well. I think the sauce had white wine and some tomato puree (not sure) but it was perfect!A must visit for anyone who wants to try great English cuisine with a wealth of history!

ay54QwFyHvQM6hdGlaVq-g.text: Rules is the oldest restaurant in London and is steeped in tradition.  It is not simply trading on history and remains an exceptional restaurant serving traditional English fare.  The last visit I started with the pea soup, which was fine but not excellent.  I then had the suckling pig, which came hoof and all.  It was tender and well portioned.  Beer selection is poor but the wine list is fairly strong.  Although the restaurant is fancy I did not experience the snooty, obnoxious service mentioned in other reviews.  To the contrary, our server could not have been more pleasant.

gvVVO2_qDl2mdraVd89Okg.text: Rules is an experience that you need to have at least once. It's the oldest restaurant in London. It's featured in Downton Abbey. My father was in town, so we treated ourselves to check it out. Yes, it is sometimes labeled as a tourist trap, but there are plenty of the higher members of London society also dining. It was established in 1794 complete with tons of stories about the royals and celebrities surrounding the establishment. There's actually a secret entrance for the royal family as well as a private club to be invited too. The walls are decorated with photos, paintings, clocks, etc. from over the years. The atmosphere was elegance left over from the days gone by. And, the food was divine!I ordered the Kate Middleton 29 signature drink to start with before switching to wine with my father. Absolutely amazing. We had course after course including filet, crab cake salad, and plenty of options for dessert. I highly recommend the experience!

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. The Experience
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Kate Middleton 29
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Menu

DcmxqIycmYzzhunVbcA0gQ.text: Many Yelp reviewers point out that this restaurant often advises they have promised your table to another guest by a certain time and seem slightly, if not completely put off by this. This is part of managing a busy restaurant and honoring reservations. If they walk in and can get a table, they're lucky! And if they had made reservations and were required to wait, they might be even more incensed. So get over it.Rules is gorgeous. Wood, tile, fireplaces, plush draperies, framed art, cut-up cozy spaces and loads of history. For this, I would gladly return. The Maitre 'd was polite and accommodating. The service adequate. The food--Veal and Morel Pie for lunch--delicious! I would ask that patrons not take children here, unless they are consistently well-behaved in public. The quarters are close and this is the kind of place you want to feel is special.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Beautiful cushions in the waiting area.
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. The stunning fireplace in the entryway.

A6Ik_p2vUCKM1wCHkluQRg.text: Yelp strikes again!  After being turned away from many traditional (and highly rated on Yelp) British pubs because we were dining with a minor, Rules Restaurant saved the day.  Despite the fact that our family was clearly under-dressed compared to the other patrons and the wait staff, they didn't turn us away.  While my husband and I do prefer to dress appropriately when we dine, we also realize that our money is green (or multi-colored as the case may be) like everyone else, our son very well mannered, and our appreciation of good food hard to beat.While I would have loved to stay for an entire fixed menu, the host had made it clear when we arrived that the only table he had for us was reserved by another party in 2 hours, so we settled for a salad and main course. All was delicious!  Clearly, my somewhat low opinion of traditional British food was formed by eating at all the wrong places!  All of our salads (green and a beet/goat cheese) were as fresh and crisp as could be and perfectly dressed.  Our "main" courses (daube of beef, the rabbit hot pot, and the wild boar pie) were simply out of this world delicious!  And the wine....oh the wine.  Perfectly paired, and perfectly French.Overall a very nice experience with excellent food and wine and a pleasant, if reserved, wait staff.  Next time I find myself in London looking for a quiet, relaxed place to dine I will know exactly where to go.(PS I marked this restaurant as "not good for kids" despite the fact that our 10 year old son enjoyed his meal and experience.  He is an unusual boy with lots of dining experiences under his belt and incredibly good restaurant manners and presence.  If yours are the same, then by all means bring them!)

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Decor d'mirror. And antler.

zaNfbfU2jDic35qkkfICng.text: I loved this place as did my wife and daughter. My daughter put this on her "fancy places list that she has been to" Yes it is one of the oldest restaurants on London and has an air of English pomp and circumstance  with it's old world theme and decor which is probably the same decor from when it first opened.I have read a few reviews that state the waiters are rude and that the people believe that they experienced racism and/or elitism. Yes they have a strict dress code as many fine establishments in the US and other countries have. Yes you need to behave like a gentleman or gentlelady and not like a yahoo. This is why people want to come here and feel like they are in sophisticated establishment. If you want to wear shorts or yell at a TV whilst your football club loses a match then go to one of the many pubs close by.We were treated extremely well, the wait staff were all great, respectful, helpful and made us all laugh. I'm not sure where some of these negative reviews are coming from.Anyway the food was fantastic and made our first night in London memorable. All the recommendations from our waiter was spot on including the steak, haunch of lamb and rabbit. He even picked us out a great wine. I actually wanted to come here because they are supposed to have a great Beef Wellington. Alas, we found out that it must be ordered 24-48 hours in advance and it is for four people. I guess we will have to preorder when we next visit London.Of note: They were very accommodating, I had made reservations weeks ago for the first night we were to be in London, 6pm reservations as I figured we would be tired flying all day, unfortunately we missed our connection flight and could not make it. I emailed them from the airport to let them know, when we got there the next day they were able to squeeze us in the night we got in at 9pm.We will defiantly be back!

bE9gmNQKJqdFknm2hjFc6A.text: Billed as London's oldest running pub, it's no surprise that reservations sell out long in advance... hence I made one the first possible day for our arrival in London.  The restaurant's walls are adorned with so many mirrors, game heads, and other paraphernalia that one could spend hours in here just staring at the decor.  Service was great and the wine was decent (albeit overpriced).  We shared a pear salad and the rib of beef for two, the latter of which came out with house-made horseradish, yorkshire pudding, and dauphinoise potatoes (one of the most amazing potato dishes I've ever had). The rib of beef is definitely portioned for two or maybe three people.  Our dessert was a british version of chocolate lava cake (I only describe it that way since I don't remember the name offhand), which was far too sugary for my palate.Total for four glasses of wine, one salad, one entree, and one dessert was £175. The beef rib dish shown on the menu as priced per person and not the total, which we missed and had an unpleasant extra £36 put on our tab.  I don't like quibbling over charges and subtext, but it's rather deceiving to not put the entire price of the dish on the menu.

aql6rNjr6fLzMCGTTmJvpQ.text: Supposedly the oldest restaurant in London, dating back to the 18th century, it's more post-Victorian in decor and style than anything else.  Service was attentive, and they offered me a newspaper to read while I waited for my food, something that would never be done at a fine restaurant in the States.I had the rabbit braised in saffron.  At least as chicken-y as rabbity, it looked very saffron-braised but didn't markedly taste of it.  Watercress soup, with bits of smoked trout in it, was somewhat more memorable.

fsVdinI9ZjUmM0Mx1fuknQ.text: Waiter was a dick.Oldest restaurant is London. Cute, kitschy decor. Extensive wine list. Yelp won't let me just write "waiter is a dick."Centrally located. Walking distance to the West End, Chinatown, Gaybourhood, Theatre District.Food yummy, look at pics.Worst service I had in London, I don't know if I would go back again, but the food was actually really good. A gratuity was also added at the end of our meal, there was only 3 of us. It was also very odd since the European system is not at all similar to an American system where large gratuity is expected or added to large parties, again 3 of us. We absolutely had that shit taken off, then this asshole basically hovered over our table while we paid. I don't know if management reads or cares about reviews or is even aware of technology since it's "the oldest in London" but this theme of crass behavior is not unfamiliar after reading other reviews. Definitely felt hostility from the waiter, only him not the rest of the staff, and it seemed racially motivated. Waiter still a dick.

1IhhxeIXU3SV9ChKeeR2Yw.text: This is a piece of history. It's the oldest continuous serving restaurant in England. Dating back to the early 1800's whilst you guys were still shooting each other. The walls are covered in wonderful charactertures depicting the incredible history of patrons. The night we dined, we saw 2 MP's from Parliament. I mean in person, not on the wall!The menu is aggressively British featuring Wild Hare, Game Pie, Partridge etc. I chose the Sole, not a fish you see in the States. Wonderfully delicate. Fish soup to start. My companions had a mixture of Pork, Duck and so on. And the puddings! We shared a Sticky Toffee Pudding and a Golden Syrup Pudding. Heaven. Nice plush velvet banquettes and attentive service made it perfect. And who knows...maybe I sat where Charles Dickens had, after all, he was a regular!

WUSCXQP0ytJ7s2xuhisg0w.text: This was my second trip to Rules, and I wanted to impress my husband with the historic restaurant. The atmosphere is awesome and historic, but I wish the waiter would have been more informative. I asked him to explain the history of the restaurant to my husband, and he told us it was written on the back of the menu which was disappointing to me. 0YSjBcKvIvyfFQcbr-8isA.text: Summary: Would leave 0 stars if I could. Don't go here. Rules has an incredibly racist and elitist atmosphere, and the food isn't anywhere near the quality to make up for it.--The oldest restaurant in London reeks with the same old attitudes of racism, classism, and elitism during its founding time of 1798. Unless there's drastic change to address the exclusionary nature of this restaurant, if you're young, not white, and want to enjoy traditional British cuisine, I would recommend taking your business elsewhere. Hopefully the current, and I directly quote from the website, "rakes, dandies and superior intelligence's who comprise its clientele" keeping the restaurant in business dies off soon.I made a reservation at 6pm from Bon Appetit's recommendation. I was very excited to share the rib of beef for two with my partner, and introduce my parents to the restaurant's history. My mother is a Chinese historical fiction writer and my father an avid photographer, so I thought it was a match made in heaven. We had come in after a fun, long day at the ZSL London Zoo, and had forgotten about the no-shorts policy stated in our email reservation. London has been unnaturally warm these past few days, and as Yankees who are used to cold drinks and air-conditioning on hot summer days, we weren't exactly focused on wearing trousers for the whole day. When we arrived at the restaurant, the doorman immediately looked my boyfriend up and down and crisply said that they have a strict no-shorts policy. My partner immediately felt humiliated and meekly told me that he would be fine going back to our hotel to change. I stood my ground, and luckily the doorman's colleague informed us that they had a spare set of trousers on hand. My boyfriend is 6'0, and the first pair of trousers that he got didn't fit him. I had to ask again for a second set. The most insulting situation was, after that entire ordeal, once he sat at the table, his legs were covered by the floor length white table cloth. Having grown up in a British International environment, I'm not new to strict dress codes, which is already rooted in classism, but if you are trying to cultivate a standardized type of clientele aesthetic, at least have a purpose to the madness. For example, London's J-Sheekey has a no-shorts policy as well, but at the very least, they have outside seating and mid-length table cloth.Our orderDrinks- A bottle of Domaine Rossignol-Fevrier Bourgogne Pinot Noir - £49.00- Draught Guiness - £6.25Comments: The wine was mediocre; looking it up, the average price is usually £17, so this was my bad for not doing more research. However, take the almost x3 markup however you'd like. Starters- Oysters: two each of Jersey Rock, Morecambe Bay, and Ostra Regal. - £18.50 total- Dorset Crab Salad - £17.95Comments: Starters were fresh enough. However, the plates were very much unceremoniously dumped onto our table with very little explanation. As well as this, when we were ordering and inquired further about the differences between the oysters (e.g. size, flavor), she told us that there was little difference between them, besides the Jersey Rock, which would be saltier. Probably one of the saddest and least detailed explanations of oysters I've ever heard. Rules proudly states, "as we are confronted with so much mediocrity... when everyone is deluged with homogeneous brands, we like to create the special." Not sure if the definition of special has changed to inadequate, but it seems Rules believes so.Mains- Roast Squab Pigeon - £29.95- Rib of Beef for Two - £35.95Comments: Mains were also fine. Yorkshire pudding was underseasoned in its bake. Meat was also underseasoned, but we were provided rock salt, pepper, gravy, and horseradish sauce. I've never been a fan of having to season my own food with salt and pepper, preferring the chef to do it for me, but I do understand that some do prefer that. To be honest, I've had better Yorkshire pudding in America at House of Prime Rib, which is concerning. Cut of meat was lackluster. Since there was a 2 hour limit for our reservation, and we finished our courses with 15 minutes to spare, we were strongly discouraged from ordering dessert, which added even more unpleasantness. However, at this point, we were just ready to leave. I usually don't write long, arduous reviews for restaurants, especially negative ones. But this has by far been one of the most disappointing restaurants I've ever been to. There's a reason why, even after over two centuries of operations, Rules still has yet to have a single Michelin star. Before I came to the restaurant, I believed the prestigious history of past diners' would be reflected in the quality of service and food. Now I feel their attendance can be explained away to not having a better option back then. But hey, there's better now elsewhere. The uptight Rules need to be left behind.

VeHUvbGJQGZwSwgapYWEMA.text: We mainly went here since it is the oldest restaurant in London and we thought that was pretty cool. It definitely felt like we stepped back into time with the old fashioned decor and photos. When we made our reservation they were very friendly and our server was nice as well. I had the chicken with mashed potatoes. I almost wish I had less chicken and more mashed potatoes. The potatoes were delicious and the chicken was pretty good. My fiancé had the duck. He enjoyed it but we wish it came with mashed potatoes or a different side. I don't like that they charged us for water and bread. It would have been nice if tap water was offered. We mainly only ordered bread because it was suggested and they told us our food would take at least 45 minutes to prepare. It was also a little stuffy inside the restaurant. For the price I didn't feel like it was worth all the money we spent. The food was good but not amazing.
