ICnfg1OBj1sxslxoFWqwBg.text: As one of the oldest existing restaurants in London, I've long considered Rules a "must" on any trip to the UK.  I've been perhaps a dozen times over the last five or six years...though my most recent visit may well be my last.Normally, their charming period decor and usually deliciously unusual game-oriented menu make them a truly unique dining experience, even in a world-class city like London.Where else can you find excellent "delicacies" like potted hare, pheasant breast, wild duck, grouse, and similar English fare?  Alas, Rules' weak point is rarely culinary; it is customer-service.  Or lack thereof.  A restaurant of the usual quality, and certainly price of Rules, should never inflict *any* the following on customers...much less all in one sitting.Here are some highlights, and some tips for the management:- Note: the only table available on the night was for 11PM.  A bit late, but the place is indeed popular.- This assumed popularity made it rather confusing to learn that, including our table...a total of three others were occupied. - We were promptly seated at 11PM.  And promptly rushed through almost every step of the experience.  We paid our bill barely an hour later, at 12:05AM.- For a restaurant of the quality and price of Rules, a customer should never feel rushed, or as if they are being timed by a stopwatch.  Nor should a customer receive such clear and unambiguous signals from the staff amounting to "Hurry it up, the staff would like to go home."- I can understand if a restaurant, for whatever reason, prefers an early or inflexible closing time, such as midnight.  But if that is indeed the case, no reservations or tables should be offered past, say, 10PM.  - If you want your customers gone by 12 midnight, and intend to begin loudly cleaning dishes, turning on all the bright lights, and reminding your customers that the bar and kitchen will close in 15 minutes...then, for heaven's sake, don't offer an 11PM seating.  Pure insanity.- Make certain you have enough food for an 11PM seating.  By the time we arrived, a solid 50%+ of the game menu was sold-out and unavailable.The food we had was indeed fantastic; at least as far as I can recall from the speed at which we needed to order and consume it.Despite the great setting and cuisine...on this night as customers, we were made to clearly feel as if we were interfering with, or delaying, the staff's other plans for the night.And that's just not acceptable.

8n8nW7Buuen-wjnINk2tgA.text: The food and service were pretty much as mentioned in other posts.  The décor was great, with lots of history on the walls. The restaurant features a genuine British menu, although the service was a bit slow. The food was solid, although not outstanding.  The sticky toffee pudding was pretty amazing. The fog salad and cold tomato soup were also very good.  Knowing that one is present at the oldest existing restaurant in London is cool, although the history of such is diminished somewhat when one peers across the street to see a combination barbecue and crawfish establishment. Our waiter told us a great story about the mural painted on the wall of Margaret Thatcher at the Falkland Islands . Since the Maître d had never heard the story, it is hard to say whether it is true or not.  Ask your waiter about it and make your own decision.

ep7DKZ9V0MydL_fMRTFh-w.text: Traditional English restaurant, excellent food and service , delicious dishes.  To my personal opinion, this is a must go restaurant if you are visiting London.  Prices are fair for the quality of food and service provided.  Ask their waiters for any reference needed.  Order the right dishes are essential to a pleasant dinning experience, since their staffs know their dishes in details, please do search for their advices when one is not sure ...

Yz5Fx2Asv4LZAoeSKglcOQ.text: Very familiar menu items but executed so exquisitely! It was just prime rib for two. However, it was the best prime rib of my life including the best old fashioned that I have ever had. Worth the trip over to England!

xiF8m-eCR1DFOOga0gjrAQ.text: Before you finish reading this review, make a reservation. There aren't many places you can visit these days where the staff will do - practically - everything they can to make you feel like you are not only going to get a special evening, but that you are actually valued. This place was like eating on a movie set in 1920. It was a throwback in the best of ways. We had been warned to come well dressed but found the rest of the people dinning were not exactly so prepared. All the same, due to a tube strike we arrived very late. A few calls along the way assured our table was still there upon our arrival on a very busy night. The staff was never hovering but it was never more than a few moments before they appeared to top off a glass, sweep crumbs, ask if we needed more of anything. They were amazing. Specializing in game and traditional English food I went with the slow cooked beef cheeks, Game soup and sticky toffee pudding. All of it was tremendous. The better half had the dressed crab and bacon wrapped monkfish which was one of the best served versions of this fish I've ever had. Pricey - but worth it. Romantic and at times loud - but in every way wonderful. For a walk back in time, dine at Rules.

uRIEykXuN7zS6gWTLT8F8Q.text: This place makes me LOL.  On one hand the food was decent.  On the other, the service was probably the most pretentious, snobby, nose up in the air @#(%@, that I have ever experienced.  Seriously, I could have practically tasted the waiters nose hairs if he came any closer to us.  It's not like we weren't well dressed, or spoke sh*tty english...it was just Mr.Belvedere doing his PMS thing.  Based on this, I couldn't recommend coming here but the food was actually decent.  While the meat dishes we we ordered were solid, the shining dish was actually the dessert.  I guess caramel soaked cakes (sticky toffee pudding) really kicks my ass.   While we were able to snag a table without reservations, they didn't seem to happy that we walked in without one.3 stars.

wiHCxZYYJsq_5vR9-zKtsg.text: I came here for my anniversary with my girlfriend about two years ago and hadn't reviewed it. The experience has stuck with us for so long. Rules has the most home-y and cosy atmosphere of any restaurant I have ever been too. Especially in winter, Rules cuddles you in it's warmth with it's rugged walls and thick, heavy meals. The restaurant is the oldest in London and is absolutely drenched in history. An awesome place to dine at if you're visiting from out of town.We had a huge cheese selection for desert and tons of wine - the way to go! I also remember loving the duck here. We will be coming back for sure!

Pm96bRMb-G60NBWVqTNETQ.text: For photos see greedydiva.blogspot.com/…  So, back in May when we still thought 23 degrees was "hot", Mama and Papa Diva came to visit me in London. Having moved to the other side of the world, forcing them to fly wedged in a plane for 24 hours all the way from Australia to visit me now and then, the least I could do was show them around some decent restaurants. I couldn't have them accidentally wandering into Bella Italia. In my excitement, I also baked them a lemon drizzle cake. But that's another story. In between cups of tea at home and polite samplings of my attempts to proximate Mama Diva's cooking prowess, we made day trips to Oxford and Brighton (where our random food findings left a bit to be desired, but the change of scenery was very nice). However, London was where I really hit my straps. Breakfast at The Wolseley was a hit (and certainly better than semi-burnt toast at my place overlooking Prowlers). Pre-theatre dinner at The Ivy was as terrific as always and "Holding the Man" at Trafalgar Studios is hilarious (and tear fest inducing - which is also quite embarrassing when you're in one of the front rows and still sobbing mercilessly in the faces of the cast as they take their bows) - although possibly not one to see with your parents unless they're as cool as mine and you all get a bit intoxicated first. We toddled up the road to Dean Street Townhouse one night, and although I prefer the noisier, clattering part around the bar, Mama and Papa Diva seemed to appreciate the quieter room on the side where we were seated in big, comfy chairs and more spacious, decadent surrounds. Perhaps a nice relief from the poky and noisy "character" of Chez Greedy. But I think the most parent-impressing place on our agenda was Rules. We saved it for our last night on the town together, and it was all fairly fabulous. Established in 1798 by Thomas Rules, Rules claims to be London's oldest restaurant. I haven't verified this, but it looks like they might be right. There's lots of old people not smiling in photos cluttered along the walls and beady eyeballs staring down from stuffed birds crammed in every cranny. It's probably not the best place for staunch vegetarians. Furnishings are rich, plush, dark and comfortable. Despite the clutter, it feels special and luxurious. Rules specialises in ultra traditional British food - there's lots of gamey stuff and potted things, with rich, wintery puddings to finish you off. It's all totally old school. My venison loin with pear, roast chicory and spiced ruby plums was decadently rich and super-gamey (£26.95). Every bite was a luxury. Mama and Papa Diva both enjoyed the rather large grilled sirloin steaks with chips, bearnaise, roasted tomato and mushroom (£22.50). We're still talking about the puddings to whoever will listen - sensational. Little Sister Diva back in Melbourne has since blocked us from her Facebook account. I had some kind of strawberry tart in a shortbread pastry while Mama Diva had a delicate strawberry souffle, both of which were absolutely divine. Papa Diva had ice-cream, which was never going to compete, but the choice had to be expected from a man who would choose a Ginger Snap biscuit over a Chocolate Royal. (All around £7.50) Despite fearing it might be stuffy and overpriced (based on a peering through the windows on past occasions), service was close to perfect - attentive, helpful, friendly, not overly fussy. Sure, it's a bit pricey, but for me it's a special occasion place (like oh, it's Wednesday) and worth every penny. The bar upstairs also looks rather tempting and I hear they make a good cocktail. Rules has 3 new fans. Traditional, straightforward food, cooked well in charismatic surrounds. You won't find anywhere like it anywhere else.

2xcgG5kBMEZYV5bprewQUA.text: This was my third time dining at Rules and sadly this visit was not the five star review I have given it in the past. I was craving the fish and chips but the fish was greasy and the peas which in the past were delicious were over-reheated and dried out. I couldn't eat them. My date's sirloin was OK; not nearly what I'd expect for the price. The atmosphere remains one of the best in London, but there are far-better venues for the price.

aKnu5Jn2rxu_q57AIIPfxQ.text: Gives whole new meaning to the term "history"  It's hard to comprehend that Rules has been around almost as long as the United States has been a country.  Started in 1798.1798!!Not a whole lotta places can brag about that.Rules knows this and takes great pride in letting everyone know it as well.  To tell the truth though, I don't blame 'em for bragging just a little.  If I owned something almost as old as dirt itself, I'd brag too.Rules specializes in game cookery.What's game cookery, you ask?Well, it's when you shoot sumthin' and cook it up.In America, game cookery occurs in places like Alabama and Mississippi where folks shoot critters like possum, squirrel, and... other folk.In England, game cookery is much more civilized.  Rules apparantly owns some pristine hunting grounds in the High Pennies fittingly named, Lartington Estate.  If you so desire, you could even reserve some time at Lartington Estate and shoot yourself up some critter for your own version of game cookery.  Personally, I prefer that Rules does the cooking.The menu's intriguing, stuff you rarely see in the states like pheasant, rabbit, snipe, grouse, and such.  Rules tries hard to keep it old school and very traditional in every aspect.  From the old-world dining room with mounted deer horns and stuffed animal heads, to the classic fruit accompaniments and condiments served with your meal.This place has got a huge novelty factor, but there is definitely an element of uniqueness about both the surroundings and your food.  After all, it isn't everyday you tuck into a "potted rabbit with mulled scrumpy apple chutney" or a "steak, kidney, and ale pudding".  Even better, the menu warns diners that the occasional buckshot might still be found in your dinner, so eat carefully.The food's surprisingly good.  The kitchen does have some skill as game meat is difficult to cook well and maintain tenderness because it's so lean.My main complaint was service.  Our server was gruff and unhelpful.  When I asked him if there was anything outstanding he would recommend, his answer was, "everything on the menu is fine."  He then took our order and proceeded to ignore us the rest of the evening.Throughout our meal, there was a distinct sense of urgency.  Usually when I eat, it's because I'm lactose intolerant.  But at Rules, urgency occurs because management sets a 2-hour time limit on your table and tells you up front when they need it back.  This was a major turn-off.To spite Rules, wifey and I took our time and dawdled at our table until the very last minute.  To sum it up: tasty critters, crappy service.Rules.

B_srH-ROsbNR73dL18jgRQ.text: I ate here for a work related dinner last year, and everything was perfect. The restaurant is beautifully furnished in an old-fashioned English style, and the service was just a bit slow but still good. Food quality was also very good, including the delicious dessert at the end. Pricey but worth a try.

3l7TpDPJpJg5jTVdayGezQ.text: WOW. I might have just found the best cocktails in London. I'm a bit blown away actually. Rules is a bit of an institution in London. The resturant is the oldest in London (I think) and dates back to 1798. Of course, I didn't come here for the food (although looking at the rest of the reviews, and judging by my hangover, I really should have), I came for celebration cocktails. I might live here. Brian Silva is a cocktail legend, and the very short list of cocktails is fantastic. All different, like nothing you've veer tried before, and constantly changing. They're at the £11-12 mark, so they're not something I'll ever be able to have every week, but they're fabulous. The champagne and pear cocktail I had was amazing. It was actually real champagne, and very yummy indeed. But the real gem was the 'Chorus Girl', which introduced me to the wonderful world of Frangelico. I've never had a cocktail that tastes of sweet French pastry before. It was a bit like sex in a glass. The friendly barmaid summed it up perfectly when she said "you want to eat your ice cubes, don't you?". I did. Fabulous cocktails, perfectly old school British decor and not at all 'Covent Garden-y'. This bar feels like a little secret (you have to go in through the restaurant), I really really hope it stays that way.

wvgIsiYABj5OsBOgqNJpoQ.text: Quality of food, wine and spirits was as excellent as the service. Despite having to seat under a scary wall painting showing Margaret Thatcher - the artist certainly must have disagreed strongly with her politics -, we enjoyed the evening a lot. Also a plus that they had at least one English white wine on their list (a Bacchus from Chapel Down vineyards). All too often, restaurants in England rely only on foreign products when it comes to wine, which is a shame. One point to note, however: We booked the table over their internet site about 10 days in advance (which worked well), and on the booking confirmation we were told that we could have the table only for 2 hours and that it would be needed afterwards. No objections against this, because we were informed immediately after the booking, and we would have to leave at that time anyway; but the restaurant was not full at this late afternoon, and I have the impression that they, by principle, seem to arrange reservation into "2-hour-slots". This means that if you want to have the freedom of staying longer than that, make it clear at the booking for how long you will need the table.

V753gb9oDGrXkdro7EmKzw.text: When I learned I would be studying in London for three and a half months, there was one place I knew I had to go to no matter what: Rules. I made a reservation just for myself because, alas, none of my fellow study abroad students were willing to shell out pounds for a meal they probably wouldn't like anyway. When I arrived, I affirmed the fact that this was the fanciest restaurant I had been to (this is back in 2006 when I was just breaking onto the dining scene.) I was addressed as "mademoiselle" (isn't this an English place?) and had my coat gently removed from my shoulders and carried off by a smartly dressed host. I was then led to a table with a seat for one person. It was nestled in a comfortable corner, and had an adorable selection of British newspapers above my head (because a single diner needs SOMETHING to do.) Since I didn't want to spend all of my money, I decided to be pretty conservative and only get an entree and dessert. As I waited and sipped my bottled water (be careful about specifying tap or else you'll be spending an extra four pounds) I looked around me. Men as far as the eye can see, and all very masculine. Business-like, buddy buddy. I saw a few couples, but groups of men dominated the restaurant. That being said, I was the only all-female party in the space.Then the food arrived. I decided to have the steak and kidney pudding, because it seemed like a classic and a dish I could never get in New York. It was delicious....except for the kidneys. Not Rules' fault, but I just discovered I don't like kidneys. A side of delicate, buttered savoy cabbage made up for it though. For dessert I went with the warm chocolate cake served with marmalade swirl ice cream and chocolate sauce. Even two and a half years later, I vividly remember being surrounded by three waiters, and how I didn't feel I deserved such attention. One placed the cake down, while another poured the thick chocolate sauce out of a silver gravy boat. Another stood guard, perhaps protecting me, who knows. I remember the bill being somewhere around 35 pounds, but definitely worth it for the experience. Whenever I can afford to return here, Rules will be one of the first stops on my list.

RXbkxp1JECxo84qzBXDkZQ.text: Frommers recommends eating at Rules as one of the things you must do while in London, and I would somewhat agree with them.  Rules is the oldest restaurant in London, and has an incredibly rich history.  That alone is reason enough to check it out if you're touring London.The service is top notch, as one would expect from an establishment of this kind.  The decor is what you would expect.  They use a lot of antlers in their decorating, which considering that they come from what was later served on a plate, is cool.  And I love that the menu has little notes for items like warning you that there may be some shot left in your game, so be careful, or that if you have a driver waiting for you, let them know and they will bring him refreshments,The food is good.  I'm not a huge fan of the style of food, so I tried to appreciate it from an unbiased review.  If you like English cooking, Rules is the place to eat.

-DrHpTRuVf7YFMQCL15DoA.text: Friend visiting from out of town and booked this restaurant way ahead as he is a die-hard Downton Abbey fan. I have to admit I am quite ignorant, besides not having watched a single episode of Downton Abbey, I have not heard of this place before!  So off we went on a Friday night for some very English and experience for the visitor.  We started off at the bar on the first floor, where we were offered some Japanese whisky, which was quite nice.  The interior does make you feel like you are teleported back in time, especially after I have downed a few glasses of scotch. Then we were ushered downstairs to our table, which was a cosy corner seat which came complete with a velvet couch.  We were recommended by another gentleman at the bar to try the grouse, which was in season but decided to go for the roast beef for two which came highly recommended by fellow yelpers.  We also ordered oysters to share, very fresh and tasty.  The roast beef was also executed to perfection.  My friend ordered the rabbit, but it tasted more like chicken and I thought that was ok.  Portions are quite sizeable leaving no room for desserts which is a pity.  Service was attentive but not intrusive.  A good place for people watching and even though it feels like a touristy kind of place, if your guest likes Downton Abbey and have some cash to spare, I would think this is a rather good option for them if they want a piece of the old London.  Prices can be on the high side given its location and fame and popularity with tourists, not the best value I have to say but I guess thats the least concern of the holiday makers especially if they choose to come to London.

i6qXeOF3FdYeBE_aYgOr6w.text: Went to Rules prior to the show, with over 90 minutes to spare. We were rushed, as service was so slow. Dinner was meh, server not personable. And the meal was very expensive. We expected much more from this establishment, especially with such high ratings here.

WglgQKs0d8SjqIUYd58TpQ.text: As I indicated on trip advisor. I rarely review. Either when it's exceptional or terrible.  In my case, it was the latter. As background, my husband and I dined at Rule's 15 years ago on our first abroad trip together. We had a VERY EARLY reservation-6:00 pm. The place was almost empty & the maitre'd managed to seat us at the very worst possible table in the entire establishment-right next to the bus boy station where the plates and glasses were clanking and crashing so loud we could barely converse. It was such a distraction the entire time, I tried to finish my sentence before the next crash. As for good, it was "meehh." For starters, we ordered garden salad and split pea soup. Both were fresh but bland. I used the salt shaker quite a bit. As main course, special of the day-lamb and guinea fowl. Both were a bit gamier than i'd expect. I love lamb so not new consuming it but you can also balance the flavor with yogurt/mint or other sauces which they didn't quite pull off. Finally, in spite of a comprehensive wine list, the 2 glasses I had were just not that good. In fact, the initial tasting of one glass had to be sent back b/c it was off.  After all that, I was eager to get out of there and skipped the dessert or their well known cheese cart altogether. We will be looking to a new place to create new memories at and recommend to our friends when visiting London.

GMXTmwznZw0kiRdERQ4AcQ.text: I ate dinner here on one of my first trips to London, with my wife and a number of her colleagues.  It was expensive, fancy, traditional, and perfect for a bunch of tourists.  We had a great time and an amazing meal.  Now that I've been to London so many times that it feels like a second home, I want to go back and look at it through very different eyes.

kRJ9EW1R2A9XrtSp-dqOgw.text: There are people in life that you will always remember.People you meet for the first time and who you may not have the chance to see again but who will stay in your mind forever. People who will turn an easy-going evening into a once in a lifetime experience. People who, within a few hours, will teach you more than you have ever dared learn, just by listening to their passion and knowledge.While enjoying this priceless experience, you suddenly feel like a child being given a lesson in humility and modesty. And, secretly, you dream of feeling that same passion for life when the alarm clock rings in the morning. But first, Rules. Trying to move with the times while reflecting is weighty history, Rules , the oldest restaurant in London, is still rife with a charming English atmosphere reminiscent of a fine Parisian bistro; waiters dressed in bow ties and armed with a 'sans-faute' service. The grouse confirms its success day after day among customers who have come to enjoy its delicate taste for more than a hundred years. Since 1798, though, some creative touches have crept into the menu, including the tasty Dressed Dorset Crab. And, as the way to celebrate the national how-how of making pudding, the Sticky Toffee Pudding with Butterscotch Sauce will definitely reconcile you with traditional English cuisine. And now, let's step Upstairs at Rules. A year ago, when Rules reconverted their first floor into a bar, giving justice back to what it had been during the war, they couldn't have made a better choice than hiring one of the most recognised bartenders that long and short drinks have ever encountered. Mastering the art of cocktails may seem as easy as mixing the right measure of liquors in the right order and shake for the appropriate length of time just like cooking is all about mixing ingredients in the right order and cooking to taste. The perfect cocktail is about respect, about love and the passion you pour into every drink you make. And this is something that the Cocktail master Upstairs at Rules has understood to the very core. Thirty years after having served his father his first cocktail, Brian Silva, bartender extraordinaire at Rules, has become a master of understanding his customers' expectations, be it to create their preferred pre-dinner drink like they've never had it before or think up the relaxing potion which will put the finishing touch on an exquisite dinner at the restaurant downstairs. With a menu of only 10 specials but more than a thousand recipes in mind (and 200 written in his little black book), when Brian Silva looks at you and pops the question,'What are you in the mood for?' you know the experience is going to be worthwhile. Put the menu away, don't give a second's thought to what you thought you were going to drink; let yourself be lead by the master's flair and know-how. A last check if the drink should be rather short, long, sweet or bitter and the whole creation process starts. Among his alchemist's laboratory of first-choice liqueurs, Brian is a flurry of activity, only slowing as he pours each measure by eye over the perfectly 2-by-2-by-3 icecubes. For a moment, you're sure he would be just as quick  although no less impressive  if he was blindfolded. 'For me, the hit of the evening is to see the smile on my customer's face when they take their first sip'. So what does Master Silva think of the infamous classic, Rosebud's OBI Long Island Iced Tea? Equal measures of all the spirits and around 25ml or less of lemon juice. The spirits don't have to be a 25ml measure they can and probably should be less, say around 15ml of each. The cocktail should be tasted first and then balanced with coca-cola to offset the lemon. Lots of ice please!

gWGoM70WrIlnX38Q4q_cxw.text: Had a wonderful pre-theatre dinner here. Service was excellent, food was very traditional and spot on.Will return when back in London town.

iSDT_Lb7TqFHFD8b2TzXPw.text: One of my favourite places. I really like the food and the atmosphere. The service is perfect as well.

0sMMYzfCzTNaBaq8_81L6g.text: For some reason, Britain was seen as the poor man of foodie Europe until quite recently. But I sense Rules, as London's oldest restaurant, has been flying the flag for fine dining since the day it opened. If you want old English charm, delightful surroundings and classic dishes, this is the place to come. But perhaps save it for a special occaision as we did  it's not cheap. The whole place retains an air of its own, as well as London's, history. All around amid the deep red, cushioned booths, there are satirical prints on the walls, and waiters cut a dash as they busy themselves in their crisp, fine livery. Service, as you would perhaps expect, is of the highest order. The menu is seasonal, and therefore changing subtly all the time. Food in a place like this is naturally cooked to order, and ingredients represent the best of British  beef, lamb, game, fish and shell fish  sourced from the finest corners of our Isles. I had a delicious and filling onion soup, akin to French soup, with a giant crouton, gloopy with juice on its underside. My partner had a perfectly prepared pigeon breast, pink and glistening. By the end of this starter I was fit to burst, but had to carry on until every last morsel was eaten from my main plate. I can't wait to return.

ffsp1ft3JTUKaAamL7eAAQ.text: This is the oldest restaurant in London, and it has aged gracefully. We have dined here several times and have never been disappointed. It's definitely too pricey to become a regular hangout but it's the perfect place to celebrate a special occasion.We usually have eaten here in the winter, so we tend to order hearty dishes that will prepare us for a walk in the brisk night. The Windsor soup with Welsh rarebit and potted rabbit with apple chutney are wonderful starters. If you want a traditional British dish for your main course, the steak and kidney pie is perfect. I also recommend the curried pheasant and rack of lamb. If you have room for dessert, try the date and toffee pudding or spotted dick, whose name unfortunately makes me think of an STD!The decor is elegant and the service is impeccable. With a starter, entree, dessert, a bottle of wine, and service, dinner for two will run about £125 on average, and it's worthy every pence.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

fbZcErCUh6LVZQ279M4DuA.text: Rules is an unforgettable experience.  It has a old gentlemen's club like feel.  There is so much to take in.  I felt a bit underdressed in my jeans.  The staff is very welcoming and accommodating.  I suggest getting a drink upstairs while you wait for your table. The food... so delicious!  Wasn't feeling adventurous enough to try a game dish so got the rib-eye.. one of the best steaks I've had.  And for dessert I had the golden syrup pudding- this is a must.  I couldn't finish my steak but had no problem eating every last bite of my dessert.

sApQJZlHfSXtz-phEsPO0w.text: I love this place...I could stop there but you really want some sort of review.I used to work over the road and when I changed jobs, I took my team here for dinner.  They loved the quaint and quirkly fish n chips (in a page of the FT) served with half a Guinness.Wonderful food in a sumptuous and comfortable atmosphere.Last time I was here Heather Mills-(McCartney) was in after getting a drubbing in the press... trust me, nicer people eat here and most of them don't seek any attention.Go, enjoy, tell them I sent you?

_tCAKt2Mhp6f5v5nCN9xEw.text: Established in 1789 by Thomas Rule, Rules boasts as being London's oldest restaurant. However, despite this, it has become more of a tourist trap, luring them into trying something from their large menu at typical tourist prices. The food they serve is that of traditional, heavy British cuisines such as game (which is sourced by Rules itself), pies, oysters and wonderfully rich puddings. The menu is extensive and enticing, and the food, depending on what you chose, not too bad, but far too expensive for what it's worth. The decor is very over the top, old-school English, where every wall is covered with ornaments of some sort, paintings and mounted heads of animals. The eccentricity in its design is amusing and is worth a look, but all in all you can get what they serve in a decent gastro-pub without all the pent up hype and at less of a dear cost.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

BuH2lVBOBB0qgXSQdj4cvQ.text: Delicious food. Nice decor. The air con was really freezing. Unfortunately the dessert of sticky toffee pudding was disappointing. Having informed them it was my birthday the only thing i got was two marshmallows and two tiny pieces of chocolate! Not even a candle on the dessert!Worth having a meal here though since all the dishes ordered were spot on. The crab on toast, fois gras, rib eye beef on the bone. All really good. Expensive.

mhRpga9ePzmzGiLi0-Grow.text: Ok, this place is not cheap, but the food and ambiance is glorious.  You eat history here and not just a fine British meal. Worth the price for a special occasion; but make sure it's for dinner. That's when they bring out the best chef.

LRuoL6zKQT2-SfLwKcRgBw.text: Fantastic food. My third time at Rules and I have to say wow.... Wow. Wow. Fantastic location, fantastic staff and fantastic food. I tried the steak and kidney pie for the main and the potted shrimp for starter both fantastic. The rest of The group went for the roast beef and the beef cheeks both excellent choices.I am now sat planning a reason to go back to Rules either for business of pleasure. This is the oldest restaurant in London and full of character and characters. The staff make you feel like your at home and you feel their commitment to the restaurant and their customers. Sat looking in my diary to seen when we can go back.....10 out of 10 from me.

tn9irLqzffaSphFgLT-XIg.text: For my friends birthday, we came for a late lunch at Rules. They accommodated us very quickly and easily. The menu here is phenomenal. Seeing as we don't do big fancy lunches or dinners often, the five of us decided to just go for it. Why not right, we are at the oldest restaurant in London after all. We started off with one of their speciality drinks called The Grouse, which is Famous Grouse, Ginger Wine and Bitters. If you've never had one, think of a Whiskey Sour but WAY better. My friends tried both styles of oysters available, they preferred the Duchy Native Oysters over the Frenchman's Creek Rock Oysters. I didn't partake, mostly due to the whole being allergic to all seafood thing. They seemed to quite enjoy it. I had the crisp wild rabbit, which was okay, but would have preferred frog legs or quail. For the main course, two of my friends decided to split the Deer loin and what was called Jugged Hare. We asked the waiter what exactly Jugged Hare was as we had never heard of it. It consists of wild hare stewed and cooked in its own blood. IN.ITS.OWN.BLOOD!. In the spirit of the afternoon, it was ordered. None of my friends liked it at all, complaining of a sharp after taste. When I gave it a go, I immediately loved it. Later on, our waiter informed us that only about 1 in 5 people that order it like it. On this afternoon, I was the one.Overall, the service was fantastic, our waiter was very friendly, helpful and put up with us when we got a bit out of hand. My rib eye steak was massive and cooked to perfection. Everything that I tried off of others plates was spectacular and the overall experience here was great. I would definitely recommend coming here if you are looking for a real nice outing.

I-XG8B_2Po0CFHmaigZr4w.text: I have to admit that the Bacon and Pea soup with minted creme fraiche is simply delicious. You also should try the Poached Loch Duart Salmon Salad- as a side dish you receive tasty potatoes and cucumbers. The main courses.. what i can say.. all are precisely-made. My favourite is Scallops with Braised Pork Cheeks. The sweet carrots are a nice addition to the scallops.

TYfud7FmhXlLN_JlnLz7rg.text: Rules is London's oldest established restaurant, dating back to 1798. It specialises in game, oysters, pies and pudding - quintessential English fare. Situated at 35 Maiden Lane it is well placed to serve pre-theatre meals although to really experience Rules I feel that one must dedicate a whole evening to sampling the delights it has to offer. The building itself is reason enough to visit this restaurant. The walls are a testament to the many famous people who have dined here. Much of the building is original with stained glass skylights and panelled walls. Due to the original nature of the building the restaurant, spread over three floors can often seem cramped and it is always very hot. One concession that the restaurant has made to modernisation is the acceptance that the staff need not run backwards and forwards to the kitchen. Each staff member now has an electronic pad which takes your order and communicates it to the kitchen instantly. So what do you eat? Perhaps you would try the cream of herb soup with roasted king scallop, celeriac and hazelnut oil (served hot or cold) or maybe the fois gras and duck terrine with walnut and raisin bread, sauterne and port jelly. Not very PC but. For main do consider whatever they have on special and expect to pay around £20 for a dish. The deer and teal come highly recommended. Then dessert. You cannot eat at Rules and not have dessert. My old favourite, a sauterne crème brulee has disappeared off the menu but I would recommend them all! The cheese board is simply spectacular. The wine list is particularly impressive from £13.95 a bottle to £395.00, something to suit most. If in doubt ask for a recommendation. I would thoroughly recommend this restaurant if you enjoy good food and a convivial atmosphere. For any veggies who are still with me this really is not the place for you. There are constant reminders of what you are eating and no mistaking a bird on a plate. Booking is almost essential here, especially at the start of the Game season (12 August) and at Christmas. If there are more than two of you do not count on getting a table.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Rules new "internet friendly" awning!

19plG3Mc9YGdxfFHjt3sZg.text: The atmosphere is nice and cosy. You should try the Pea and Bacon soup and also the Chargrilled leg of lamp- they are mouth-watering and delicious.

8aNxhHIa0ikxmCMNactA5Q.text: Since discovering this place a couple years back, I've made it a point to visit Rules on every trip to London.This time, my wife was with me.  Note:  we did not have time to go back and change at the hotel before dinner, so we were both wearing jeans although she had a blouse (and North Face jacket) and I had a sport/dress shirt.  We did feel a bit out of place although there were a couple others in jeans and one guy with jeans and a T-shirt.  However, 95% were wearing suits or sport coats and the female equivalent.Everything we got was delicious:  asparagus (hot) and crab salad to start, venison and steak for main, and chocolate pudding and toffee pudding for desserts.As the daughter of a hunter, my wife especially liked the venison and said it was the best she had ever had.  I really dislike game meats, but enjoyed this venison.Highly recommended!

O-eRDE6FjZKvR43Z8VQMCw.text: Was in London for vacation and this was a recommendation of a friend.  THe food and atmosphere were awesome. The beef was tender and delicious.  Loved it!

3Wzd558jch5pbPIsC8dkEQ.text: Eat here!  Game, very fresh fish, clubroom feel and look.  Very good experience, service and food.  Expensive too.Worth the expense.  Eat here.

avtkaPrwRQvZgABM7Imt9w.text: I was extremely concerned when I went to Rules for the first time, as this place's reputation has the unfortunate potential of being a disappointing tourist trap. Descriptives like a "London landmark" and "oldest restaurant" could turn out to be dining gold, but it could also go south just as quickly. Well, my fears were unfounded. If you like the traditional and comfortable meat and potato menu along with proper yet friendly service, you will love Rules. You start (more likely than not) with a cocktail upstairs in the bar as you await for your table. Unfortunately, they don't serve food at the bar for us business travellers sometimes dining alone, but even at a table, the Rules experience is worth it, with or without a dining companion. As others have stated, the dress code is dinner proper, but i think you can get away with anything so long as you don't look like you've just stepped off a beach in Ibiza. Going for an all-meat theme, I started with the Fois Gras which was a pate block of superb flavor and silky smooth texture. The roast beef for two was cooked perfectly with excellent flavor from the ageing. But more than just the perfect beef were the accouterments that were served, from the crispy yet slightly chewy yorshire pudding to the freshly graded creamed horseradish to the uniquely savoury and unfamiliar (at least to stupid Americans like me) creamed leeks. When you're sick of the cornish pastry, fish and chips and Indian Curry and crave something familiar yet still undeniably English, give Rules a try. Be prepared for a healthy bill at the end, but given the service, the flavors and the traditional setting, it's well worth it.

IPQa4q_kqhNPGGnWpQ7QWA.text: With the uneven floors, waiter attire and pictures on the wall, you really feel like you're stepping back in time. The menu changes according to the hunting season, but we got the rabbit rillete, lamb and venison which were all excellent. And drinking beer out of a silver chalice is always fun!

ehpsj1wc-2qfAsKYpFn4tg.text: We booked for 6.00pm on Sunday evening, on entering the restaurant I was welcomed by the manager saying "he needed the table back by 8.00" (bearing in mind I had booked here several weeks prior I was tempted to turn around and walk out). However as there were four of us and we where celebrating the other couples second wedding anniversary I thought I would keep stum (anyway if we hadn't finished that would be his problem not ours). We each had our starters two opting for the dressed Crab, and two choosing the Coronation Terrine which I must say was excellent. For our main course my partner choose Venison Loin, I choose the Duck breast which was cooked exactly as requested, and the other couple opted for Steak and Kidney pie and fish pie, both I was reliably informed was excellent. The Treacle sponge pudding I had for dessert finished the evening of perfectly. We did finish later than 8.00pm but fortunately we where not interrupted so didn't have to get my stroppy head on, and were all very satisfied with the evening. Looking at some of the other meals leaving the kitchen these also looked excellent especially the HUGE Yorkshire puddings. The restaurant is reputed to be the oldest in London dating back to 1798, the decor is certainly unique and adds to the occasion. Don't expect a cheap night here but do expect a pleasant one. The only criticism I would make has already been mentioned but didn't spoil our evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Rules Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

pmR0vBM05gwsajX_LYy-IQ.text: This restaurant's claim to fame is being the "oldest" restaurant in London...I'm a bit of a sucker for history so I had to check it out. I had dinner here before going to see the "Producers" and it is located conveniently from "theatreland" about a 5min walk from the Theatre Royal Drury Lane where the Producers was playing at the time. Anyways, on to the food. For a started I had the smoked salmon. Best smoked salmon I've had (in London). For my main, I had a steamed lobster with a side of mash...the lobster was succulent, well prepared, and tasted divine. The mash was also very good, just the right hint of butter. I finished with a Golden Treacle Sponge Pudding with custard. Their menu does change frequently and they have all the traditional English favorites (i.e. Brown Windsor Soup, Steak & Kidney Pie, etc.) They also feature fresh game and when it's in season, Grouse...if you're into Grouse. I like how they have a little disclaimer on the menu stating that the fresh game may contain "shot" lol.I recommend this place even though some would argue it's a tourist trap.They have a very respectable selection of Scotch too.

Tzu6oU7q1ak1nsLthDpG4Q.text: Loved the attitude of the staff. Very polite and prompt. The food was obviously great.

5uPI6mADYq-tmrefzWrBag.text: If you are going to dine alone and plow through a copy of Dickens's Tale of Two Cities, then Rules (Charing Cross) is the place for you.  If you are in the company of someone special, doubly so.  Rules is an institution, and requires an open mind.  I would recommend reservations for a more relaxed experience.  I arrived without one and was advised that I could be seated immediately (810p) but would have to finish by (915p).  I took this in stride, but I can see why it may be bothersome to people in a party of more than one.Rules has two tables for one, by the way.  There is no seating at the bar.My suggestion for Rules is that you have at least one dish you would never in your life order, or much less get where you live.  Mine was the Crisp Wild Rabbit with Stornaway Black Pudding and Bacon Salad.  This was on the recommendation of my waiter, a fellow foodie and Whole Foods shopper.  The rabbit was really, really good.  Breaded and fried in delicate strips.  But the Black Pudding, which is made from pig's blood, knocked me out!  This was food rich and flavor and tradition.  Dickens leaped from the pages of my book.  The bacon salad consisted of bacon, lettuce, and a light dressing.But it didn't stop there; I went on to have Rack (2) of West Sussex Lamp with Spinach.  While the spinach was nothing out of the ordinary, the lamb came excellently prepared and served simply sans sauce.My last suggestion for Rules is this: bring your wallet because it ain't cheap but it's worth every cent.I recently found a great movie that they have on their website rules.co.uk  Look on the lower right for the Clark Gable movie link.
